data.title: Weightlifting: A 40-year first for USA’s Morris
data.meta_description: Well done, Hampton Morris.He couldn’t quite sustain his challenge for silver in the men’s 61kg weightlifting, but his bronze is the first weightlifting Olympic medal claimed by an American man since 1984 — when Guy Carlton took bronze in the men’s heavyweight division. Great work, Hampton.
data.text:
Everything that happened on Day 12 of the 2024 Paris Olympics

Quincy Hall won Olympic gold in the men’s 400m final and the United States women’s basketball team beat Nigeria 88-74

52 New Updates

Paris Olympics 2024 — Day 12

Quincy Hall won Olympic gold in the men’s 400m final on Wednesday by just four-hundredths of a second in another dramatic photo finish at Paris 2024.

Britain’s Matthew Hudson-Smith set a new European record but he was pipped at the post by Hall, who won gold in a personal best 43.40.

Elsewhere, Noah Lyles — who triumphed in the men’s 100m final on Sunday night in an even closer final — progressed in the 200m by finishing second in his semifinal.

At Le Golf National, defending Olympic champion and world No 1 Nelly Korda carded a level-par 72 in her first round. And the United States women’s basketball team beat Nigeria 88-74.

Medal table | How to follow | U.S. women's basketball

Weightlifting: A 40-year first for USA’s Morris

Well done, Hampton Morris.

He couldn’t quite sustain his challenge for silver in the men’s 61kg weightlifting, but his bronze is the first weightlifting Olympic medal claimed by an American man since 1984 — when Guy Carlton took bronze in the men’s heavyweight division.

Great work, Hampton.

Advertisement

Skateboarding: USA's Schaar back into second

American Tom Schaar also completes a wildly good second run, one which earns him a score of 92.23 out of 100, and sees him overtake compatriot Tate Carew into second place and the silver medal position in the men's park skateboarding final.

Schaar, seventh in the running order of eight, is followed by Keegan Palmer of Australia, who falls off his board midway through his second run, but is still top with 93.11 and in the gold medal position.

Each of the eight men has one more attempt left, each. Can anyone make themselves a hero?

Skateboarding: USA's Tate Carew goes second with 91.17!

American Tate Carew just completed his second run in the men's park skateboarding final after just an 18.06 first up following an incomplete run.

Sporting a loose cream-coloured shirt, he smashes it, a full run, and he holds up his board to the fans, with his parents beaming proudly on the sidelines. Snoop Dogg and Tony Hawk, two legends of the game, were loving it!

It's a 91.17!

He has gone into silver medal position, above compatriot Thomas Schaar and only behind Keegan Palmer in the leaderboard!

"Oh my God, dude," he says to himself when the score is announced.

Meet the fastest man in the world! No, not that one...

The morning after American sprinter Noah Lyles was anointed the fastest man on earth, an 18-year-old chess aficionado who still lives at home with his parents stopped Lyles in the Olympic village, with a bit of a reality check for the gold medalist:

“Unfortunately,” Sam Watson told Lyles, “I am the fastest man in the world.” Imagine Lyles’ initial surprise given this particularly bold moment, and then imagine his utter shock to learn that Watson wasn’t necessarily lying.

Because Lyles can certainly stake claim to being the fastest man on earth (horizontally), but Watson can say the same about himself (vertically). The Olympics isn’t a place that lends itself to sharing glory, but this is a case of exactly that — the fastest man in the world and the other fastest man in the world.

Yesterday, Watson wasted no time in breaking the world record — the third time he had done so in three months. In front of a packed crowd in sweltering heat, he scaled the equivalent of a five-story building in 4.75 seconds — a real-life Spiderman. Read more below.

GO FURTHER

Meet the fastest man in the world: No, not Noah Lyles — speed climber Sam Watson

Skateboarding: Olympic final under way

At the men's park skateboarding final at the Place de la Concorde, and four guys in out of eight, there have been no clean runs yet.

Fortunately everyone gets three tries.

The best score wins.

Team USA's Tom Schaar recorded the first clean score of 90.11, with Australian Keegan Palmer top with 93.11 after the full first round. Only two completed runs though.

Into the second round.

Weightlifting: USA’s Morris wins bronze, China’s Li takes gold!

A thrilling contest in the men’s 61kg has come to an end and Hampton Morris has won a long-awaited Olympic weightlifting bronze for the United States.

After a 126kg snatch, he was forced to attempt a world-record 178kg clean and jerk, but couldn’t quite pull it off.

His combined total of 298kg was enough for third place and the bronze medal.

That meant Thailand’s Theerapong Silachai (303kg) took silver while it was another gold for China who had Li Fabin to thank for a mammoth 310kg total, including an Olympic record of 143kg in the snatch.

Advertisement

Volleyball: USA respond to take semis initiative

As for the indoor variety, the U.S. have recovered well from narrowly losing the opening set (25-23) of their semifinal against Poland.

The United States responded by taking the second 27-25, and has just smashed the Poles in the third, 25-14.

That puts the U.S. one set from a return to the Olympic final — a title they last won at Beijing in 2008.

Beach volleyball: Canada up and running in quarters

We’ve got a volleyball double-header on right now.

On the sandy stuff under the Eiffel Tower, the Canadian duo of Melissa Humana-Paredes and Brandie Wilkerson have taken their first set against Spain’s Daniela Alvarez and Tania Moreno, 21-18 in their beach volleyball quarterfinal.

They move to within one set of the semis.

Sadly, the U.S. involvement in the women’s competition ended last night with defeat against Switzerland, who will await the winners of this one in the last four.

Basketball: Belgium into women's semifinal after beating Spain

The Spanish deserve a lot of credit for their wonderful sportsmanship earlier in the match but it is Belgium who go through to the semifinal after a 79-66 victory.

Spain took it to within 11 points in the last quarter but ultimately the Belgians were just a bit too good for their opponents, and now reach the Olympic semifinals in just their second appearance at the Games.

Julie Vanloo, who nailed a clutch 3 amid her 13 points and seven assists, said:

💬 “It’s been a difficult week for us. After starting so badly, I think everyone counted us out. But against all odds we’ve fought back, and it’s amazing (to progress).”

They join Australia in the semis, who will play the winner from the last quarterfinal. Here is what remains today:

Germany vs France at 6pm local time, 12pm/midday ET, 9am PT, 5pm BST

United States vs Nigeria at 8.30pm local time, 2.30pm ET, 11.30am PT, 7.30pm BST

Diving: Bacon and Gibson out in the 3m springboard prelims

There will be no U.S. divers in the women’s 3m springboard semifinals.

Alison Gibson was unable to recover from her first-round mistake and finished in last place. Sarah Bacon fared slightly better but finished agonisingly outside of the qualifying positions — only the top 18 divers progress to the semifinals, with Bacon finishing 19th.

China’s pursuit of a clean sweep in the diving pool continues as Chen Yiwen qualified in first place, almost 20 points clear of Australia’s Maddison Keeney in second.

Sailing: Matt Wearn retains his Olympic title

In the men's dinghy medal race Australian Matt Wearn, pictured, has retained his Olympic title from Tokyo, becoming the first man to secure successive gold medals in the Laser (ILCA7) class.

Cyprus’ Pavlos Kontides, a silver medallist at London 2012, takes another silver here, with Peruvian Stefano Peschiera edging out Hungary's Jonatan Vadnai to bronze.

That is Peru’s first Olympic medal in any sport since 1992, and just the second Cypriot medal in history.

Advertisement

Water polo: Serbia await if USA makes semis

The team events are producing some stunning finishes at Paris 2024 today.

After the drama of the men’s handball, it’s the turn of the water polo where Serbia has pinched victory in its quarterfinal with Greece, 12-11.

Greece thought they had earned a penalty shootout with an equalizer leaving just six seconds to play, through Angelos Vlachopoulos.

But Serbia was having none of that, and Nikola Jaksic pinged in a stunner from 6m, in off the underside of the bar.

And with that, Greek hearts were broken and Serbia make Friday’s semifinals where they will face either the United States or Australia, who clash in the pool in the coming hours.

Earlier today, Croatia beat Spain 10-8 and will face either Italy or Hungary, who play out the last quarterfinal tie this evening.

Volleyball: Fans are missing U.S. action

The real question is after the first set, why is Peacock choosing to run so many commercials during game action?

Fans are missing out.

Volleyball: U.S. men lose first set against Poland in semifinal

Not the start the USA will have wanted to their men’s volleyball semifinal against Poland.

A super tight first set between the two sides was edged 25-23 by the Europeans and they are a set away from the gold medal match.

The U.S. has plenty of time to react, but will want to avoid going two sets behind.

What to watch: Lyles and the men’s 200m semis

Time: 2:02pm ET, 8:02pm in Paris

TV: NBC, Peacock

The recently anointed fastest man in the world, Noah Lyles, will be joined in the 200m semifinals by sprinters like defending champion Andre de Grasse (Canada), Erriyon Knighton (USA), Kenny Bednarek (USA) and Letsile Tebogo (Botswana).

Legendary sprinter Usain Bolt won this race across three consecutive Olympics, prior to De Grasse.

Lyles is looking to be the first American man to win gold in the 100m and 200m since Carl Lewis in 1984. Lyles won the 100m on Sunday, over Bednarek and Tebogo, and will look to build on his success tonight.

The 200m final is tomorrow.

GO FURTHER

What to watch at Olympics today: U.S. women’s hoops enters knockout round and a busy track schedule

Hockey: Netherlands into women’s final again

In the women’s hockey semifinal Netherlands, who beat Britain 3-1 in the quarters, have beaten Argentina 3-0 to reach the final.

Luna Noa Fokke, Laura Nunnink and Yibbi Jansen scored the goals as the Dutch beat the team they also got the better of in the final at the Tokyo Games, where they won 3-1.

Netherlands will now play either Belgium or China for the gold medal, those two teams clashing in the second semi at 7pm local time, 1pm ET, 10am PT, 6pm BST.

The final is on Friday at 8pm local time, 7pm BST, 2pm ET, 11am PT.

Advertisement

Diving: Gibson receives zero score after mistake in 3m springboard prelims

A busy day in the diving pool continues.

We saw the men’s 3m springboard prelims earlier and now it is time for the women to take to the board.

There is U.S. interest in this one as Sarah Bacon and Alison Gibson are bidding for a place in the semifinal — 18 of the 28 divers will qualify for the semifinal.

Gibson’s hopes are hanging by a thread after two dives though, as she caught the board with her feet on her way into the pool and entered on her knees.

Ouch.

Basketball: Belgium’s creditable show of sportsmanship

In the women’s basketball quarterfinal, Belgium’s Becky Massey was called for a travel in the third quarter when she tried to call for a timeout mid-play after rolling her ankle.

Spain inbounded the ball, then placed it straight out of bound to return the possession back to Belgium.

A noble decision when losing by 18 points in the quarterfinals of the Olympics.

The Belgian players, and the crowd, applaud in unison at that show of sportsmanship.

Handball: Germany break French hearts

What a brilliant sport and an incredible end in the men’s handball quarterfinal at Pierre Mauroy Stadium in Lille.

Germany was six goals down at one point in regulation, before that remarkable comeback (and France implosion) in the final six seconds. The drama continued all the way through to the last seconds of overtime too.

With 10 seconds of overtime left, Nedim Remili found an equalizer for the host and defending champion — who had just been restored to parity after a player suspension. But the 22-year-old who drew Germany level in regulation, Renars Uscins, immediately restored its lead with four seconds to play.

There was still time for a big save from Germany goalkeeper David Spaeth to deny Valentin Porte, and then survive a quick penalty check after the buzzer. But in the end, France lost out as Germany made the final 35-34.

Dika Mem will have to live with his error at the end of regulation, while the event ends with a lengthy reception from France handball veteran and legend, 1,300-goal Nikola Karabatic, as he signs off on a stellar career.

Load more updates
